ANDROGENS

  • Pregnancy
  • Hepatic impairment
  • Renal impairment
  • Contra indications
  • Side effects
  • Patient and carer advice
  • Cautions
  • Monitoring requirements
  • Drugs in class

Advice when patient is pregnant

Avoid—causes masculinisation of female fetus.

Advice regarding hepatic impairment

Avoid if possible—fluid retention and dose-related toxicity.

Advice regarding renal impairment

Caution—potential for fluid retention.

Contra indications

  • Breast cancer in males
  • history of liver tumours
  • hypercalcaemia
  • prostate cancer

Known side effects

General side effects

commonOrVeryCommon: Acne, androgenic effects (to be assessed regularly in women), anxiety, arthralgia, asthenia, changes in libido, cholestatic jaundice, depression, electrolyte disturbances, excessive duration of penile erection, excessive frequency of penile erection, gastro-intestinal bleeding, gynaecomastia, headache, hirsutism, hypercalcaemia, hypertension, increased bone growth, irritability, male-pattern baldness, muscle cramps, nausea, nervousness, oedema, paraesthesia, polycythaemia, precocious sexual development in pre-pubertal males, premature closure of epiphyses in pre-pubertal males, prostate abnormalities, prostate cancer, pruritus, seborrhoea, sodium retention, suppression of virilism in women, vomiting, weight gain,

rare: Liver tumours,

notKnown: Sleep apnoea,

Polycythaemia

Stop treatment or reduce dose if severe polycythaemia occurs.

Advice for patients and carers

Androgenic effects in women

Women should be advised to report any signs of virilisation e.g. deepening of the voice or hirsutism.

Cautions regarding administration

  • Cardiac impairment
  • diabetes mellitus
  • elderly
  • epilepsy
  • hypertension
  • ischaemic heart disease
  • migraine
  • pre-pubertal boys (fusion of epiphyses is hastened and may result in short stature)—statural growth and sexual development should be monitored
  • skeletal metastases—risk of hypercalcaemia or hypercalciuria (if this occurs, treat appropriately and restart treatment once normal serum calcium concentration restored)
  • sleep apnoea
  • stop treatment or reduce dose if severe polycythaemia occurs
  • tumours—risk of hypercalcaemia or hypercalciuria (if this occurs, treat appropriately and restart treatment once normal serum calcium concentration restored)

Monitoring requirements

Patient parameters

Monitor prostate and PSA in men over 45 years.

Monitor haematocrit and haemoglobulin before treatment , every three months for the first year, and yearly thereafter.

Drugs in the class of ANDROGENS

  • TESTOSTERONE
  • TESTOSTERONE ENANTATE
  • TESTOSTERONE PROPIONATE
  • TESTOSTERONE UNDECANOATE
  • TESTOSTERONE DECANOATE, ISOCAPROATE, PHENYLPROPIONATE AND PROPIONATE
  • MESTEROLONE
